conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two particles, A and B, moving from rest on a horizontal plane with a v-t graph provided.
The v-t graph has time on the x-axis and velocity on the y-axis with markings for times t0, 2t0, 3t0, up to 6t0.
Particle A's velocity increases to 2v0 at t0 and decreases to zero by 3t0. Particle B's velocity increases to v0 at 5t0 and decreases to zero by 6t0.
Both particles start from rest, so their initial velocities are zero.
Particle A accelerates to 2v0 in time t0 and decelerates to zero in the next 2t0.
Particle B accelerates to v0 in 5t0 and decelerates to zero in the last t0.
Acceleration is the slope of the velocity-time graph.
For particle A during acceleration, the slope is 2v0/t0.
For particle A during deceleration, the slope is -v0/t0.
For particle B during acceleration, the slope is v0/(5t0).
For particle B during deceleration, the slope is -v0/t0.
The magnitudes of the accelerations during deceleration for A and B are both v0/t0.
The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration during deceleration for A to B is 1.
Re-evaluation confirms the ratio is indeed 1.
Rechecking the graph confirms particle A decelerates from 2v0 to 0 in 2t0 and particle B decelerates from v0 to 0 in t0.
Final confirmation that both have the same magnitude of deceleration, which is v0/t0.
